initial checking of OCR text against PDF; encoded

body.p: CASE.—Private Charles Rowe, Co. K, 139th New York Volunteers, aged 21 years, was wounded at the battle of Cold Harbor, Virginia, June 3d, 1864, by a conoidal musket ball, which fractured a portion of the left parietal bone. On the same day, he was admitted to the field hospital of the Eighteenth Corps, and transferred as follows: on June 8th, to the Fairfax Seminary Hospital; on June 29th, to the McClellan Hospital, Philadelphia; on December 10th, to the Filbert Street Hospital; and on May 12th, 1865, to the Satterlee Hospital, where he was discharged on June 16th, 1865, and pensioned. On October 30th, 1865, Pension Examiner Charles Rowland reported the patient suffering from partial deafness, constant pain in the head, and impaired memory. He rates his disability one-half, and temporary.
